title: What should I buy a PC or a Smartphone? - Quora

response.answer_text: This maybe a matter of opinion, but you will use a smartphone more often than a computer, even though a computer is much more versitile. . Computers can do almost everything a smartphone can do, and MORE (except fit in your pocket, which is debatable, and make calls over 2G, also debatable) Smartphones can do many things similar to a computer, but their usefulness extends beyound a computer due to portability - replacing your watch, a phone, diary, web-book, gameboy, ipod, etc etc. . Ofc you will not be able to do ‘serious work related activities’ like word, exel, powerpoint (even though these may or maynot exist in the app stores) because power and display size is required to aide productivity. Smartphones just too small and not powerful enough to do the crunching you desire. They may offer half cut word / excel / etc. but you will take twice as long (or longer) to do the same job than on a computer. . IMO a smartphone is probably a better buy than a computer, but you need to know why you want a device before you buy it … a smartphone isnt a good choice if youre going to be going to UNI and need something that can install programs and print out 100’s of pages of work.

I live with that dilemma everyday. I currently have only a smartphone. It's a long story, but suffice it to say that I became separated from a very powerful Mac computer about five years ago. And having worked in the computer industry since the seventies, I've pretty much always had at least a fairly high end computer. So I suffer “separation syndrome" almost everyday. And in the process of becoming separated from my computer, I also became separated from pretty much everything else I owned, including my home. Which means there's currently no way I can afford to purchase another computer. That said, having a smartphone has turned out to be my savior, since it functions as my communications device, my computer, my fitness tracker, and my entertainment center. So having lived both “lives", if you can only afford either a computer or a smartphone, but not both, the smartphone is definitely the way to go. And if that's the case, I would go with an Android device, since much in the way Windows can run software that Mac OS can't (yes, I am fully aware that Macs are dual boot, but iPhones aren't), there are a lot more apps for Android than iOS, especially where tools and utilities are concerned.

Which one has better specifications? , a phone or a computer? if a computer , it is better to buy a computer , however, you can buy a laptop instead if you like to get something portable. It is recommended to buy them both , they both are important. You cannot stay alive with only a phone , but you can stay alive with only a computer (or even a laptop). Imagine something went wrong with your newest smartphone (For an example : the firmware has errors , your smartphone couldn’t bootup) , What will you do while you don’t have a computer? With a computer (and an internet connection too!) you’ll be able to re-flash your phone’s firmware without going outside and buying a new firmware upgrade from others. Smartphones are able to do what a computer is able to do , but smartphones are able to become stolen by thefts , easier than a computer. You are able to do a lot with only a smart phone , but with low-specs phone, no , a computer is really recommended. Phones are good for everyday’s usage (not for productivity though) , because phone’s CPU is not as good as a computer’s CPU. Hope it help.

It depends entirely on your needs and tastes. Most things you can do on a computer you can also do on many modern smartphones. The question is mostly, what kind of tasks you do on a regular basis and what type of interface you are most comfortable with. For me personally, I have a desktop computer and a smartphone. Don’t have a tablet or laptop. I highly prefer sitting comfortably at my desk using a keyboard and mouse and a fast computer with terabytes of storage I don’t have to worry about filling up anytime soon, a fast stable wired Internet connection that does not slow down if there are too many people around, and a 22 inch monitor as opposed to the tiny 6 inch screen of my phone. I do a few tasks that are far easier and better done in the computer than in the cell phone such as simple video editing, photo post-processing and working with documents such as Excel spreadsheets, letters and such, easier to work with in a large screen and physical keyboard. There are only three applications found both in my Windows computer and my Android phone. One is a weather radar application, another is an astronomy application and MS Excel. I hardly use Excel in the phone but I have it in case I need to access one important spreadsheet that I need to use often that is stored in the cloud and available anywhere to both devices. For social media I only do Facebook and much prefer to do so in my desktop computer. Spent some time several times during the day and not being constantly glued to Facebook on my cell phone. I really hate being constantly being bombarded by notifications in my cell phone so most applications are either limited on what notifications they generate or are completely restricted from doing so. For watching videos online, I also prefer the desktop computer because I can see them in my 40 inch TV rather than the 6 inch display in my phone. My phone spends most of the day on top of the (computer) desk, night stand or in my pocket. I do use it a lot for navigation in my car via Android Auto. So in my case, it is wise to have both. And they are used for different purposes.

Between a computer or a smartphone, it depends on the workload really. Even CAD operations can be done on a smartphone these days, but trying to draft a multi-storey building on a smartphone is impractical to say the least. And before I bought my computer, I was 100% reliant on my smartphone, even though I was restricted to just games, calls, texts, and social media. Maybe some office software use like WPS Office (especially when running D&D or other TRPGs). Computers are power houses compared to smartphones, and getting it can unlock so many more things that you can do than smartphones ever will. But just because they’re better in almost every way, doesn’t necessarily make them the better buy; sometimes the portability is more important than most other features. If you’re always on the go, and don’t mind keeping things lean by comparison, go smartphones. If you need to do a lot more — and I do mean a LOT more — and don’t mind the lack of portability (or in the case of laptops, a much bulkier but still portable device), go computer.

You could buy a pc and combine it with a cheaper smartphone. That way you won’t miss out many features that you can have with a smartphone and a computer. If you want to use the pc for some tasks that require a lot of processing and graphics power, like video editing, or some office work which does not require you to be on the move all the time, a pc will be much better suited. You can’t type that well on a smartphone. Now you can attach a keyboard to a smartphone, but it won’t have a large display and the typing speed can be somewhat limited. I really think a smartphone is more an appliance that works well for situations when you can’t use a laptop, but still need to check mail or send a reply, take photos etc. These days you can combine a phone via windows 10 and send photos via wi-fi to the pc. If you need portability you should consider a laptop, however a desktop is cheaper and can have more power than a laptop for the same amount of money. Laptops can be quite expensive in comparison to a regular PC, but basic models will be good for office work and internet browsing.
